para.paratext:
Federal case law recognizes a privilege for confidential communications between a psychotherapist and patient.[
1] The federal psychotherapist-patient privilege was first recognized by the United States Supreme Court in Jaffee v. Redmond .[
2] Both the federal and Georgia rule extend beyond just psychotherapists and psychiatrists to include clinical social workers.[
3] The Ninth Circuit has further extended the privilege to cover unlicensed counselors,[4] but Georgia has limited the privilege to licensed mental health professionals, including psychiatrists, psychologists, licensed clinical social worker, clinical nurse specialist in psychiatric/mental health, licensed marriage and family therapists, or licensed professional counselor.[
5]

The federal privilege applies only where the communications were made in the course of treatment.[
6] Georgia's privilege is slightly more protective, making communications during treatment or in contemplation of treatment privileged.[
7] However, in both state and federal practice, there must be a reasonable expectation of privacy in the communication for the privilege to apply.[
8] The fact of treatment and date of treatment are not protected under the federal privilege.[
9] Georgia courts have a similar restriction.[
10]

There are several exceptions to the federal privilege. First, the mental health care provider may testify at the civil commitment hearing about communications.[
11] However, Georgia courts protect communications from disclosure in proceedings to commit a patient for evaluation, except when waived by a patient.[
12] Like Georgia, the federal courts also do not generally recognize the privilege where the mental health examination was mandatory especially if there were no reasonable expectation of privacy.[
13] The Georgia statutory mental health privilege, however, may be invoked whenever a relationship between mental health provider and patient existed to the extent that actual treatment was given or contemplated, regardless of whether such treatment was voluntary.[
14]

Georgia does recognize an evidentiary privilege for communications with a broad range of mental health professionals under O.C.G.A. §§ 24-5-501(a)(5) to (8) and 43-39-16. No definition of a “psychiatrist” appears in the Georgia Code, but it has been interpreted to mean “a person licensed to practice medicine, or reasonably believed by the patient so to be, who devotes a substantial portion of his or her time engaged in the diagnosis and treatment of a mental or emotional condition, including alcohol or drug addiction.”
[15] Therefore, a physician does not have to practice only psychiatry or be specially trained to practice psychiatry for the privilege to apply. A broad definition of the term “psychiatrist” “protects communications of the patient who seeks treatment for mental disorders from a medical doctor with the expectation that the communications will be confidential.”
[16] It likewise “acknowledges the absence of a general physician-patient privilege in this state by restricting privilege to medical doctors who spend a significant amount of time diagnosing and treating mental illness”[17] and “is fair in protecting people who need psychiatric treatment but live in an area of the state not served by a physician who has completed post-graduate training in psychiatry.”
[18] Ultimately, “whether an examining physician is or is not a psychiatrist is a matter which may affect the extent of his expertise in evaluating mental condition[s], and therefore may affect the weight of any opinion or evaluation, … but it does not affect the admissibility.”
[19]

Also, the mental health privilege applies to communications made to a number of other mental health professionals, including licensed clinical social workers, clinical nurse specialists in psychiatric/mental health, licensed marriage and family therapists, licensed professional counselors, and licensed associate professional counselors[20] during the psychotherapeutic relationship.[
21] The privilege protects both confidential communications with these mental health professionals and communications among or between these professionals about a treated patient.[
22] The privilege will not be extended, however, to communications made to nurses or attendants of a mental health professional, unless it can be shown that they were acting as agents of the attending professional.[
23] Likewise, no evidentiary privilege is recognized for communications between a hospital and patient.[
24] For communications with a mental health professional to be deemed privileged, the patient must have had a reasonable expectation of confidentiality. Accordingly, the presence of a third party will almost always destroy the confidentiality of the communication, unless the third party is present as “a necessary or customary participant in the consultation and treatment.”
[25]

The confidentiality communications with a mental health professional has been questioned when such communications are the result of court ordered treatment.[
26] Clearly, before the statutory mental health privilege may be invoked, “the requisite relationship of [mental health provider] and patient must have existed to the extent that treatment was given or contemplated.”
[27]

At one time, Georgia courts held that the mental health privilege applied only in cases in which the patient “voluntarily seeks treatment.”[
28] However, the Georgia Supreme Court rejected that rule in the 2005 case of State v. Herendeen .[
29] Therein, the state sought discovery of medical records from psychologists who treated molestation victims pursuant to an order from the Division of Families and Children's Services (DFCS). The trial court, believing that the mental health privilege could only be invoked when the patient voluntarily sought treatment, concluded that the children's records were not subject to the privilege because they were made pursuant to a court order. Upon review, the Georgia Supreme Court expressly disapproved language in prior cases stating that the privilege is formed only when the patient “voluntarily seeks treatment” and clarified that the statutory mental health privilege may be invoked whenever a relationship between mental health provider and patient existed to the extent that actual treatment was given or contemplated. Generally, such a relationship does not exist when the mental health provider is appointed by the court to solely evaluate a person's mental state. Similarly, no professional provider-patient relationship is formed when the parties are otherwise compelled to undergo “mental evaluation.” Accordingly, the Court concluded that the communication between the molestation victims and the psychologists was privileged because the ordered evaluation included treatment and therapy of the victims.[
30]

Although confidential communications between the mental health care professional and a patient are absolutely privileged, mental health records are not.[
31] The names of psychiatric clients, payments made by them, and names in a daily appointment book are not privileged.[
32] The same is true of records showing hospitalization for mental health evaluation and the dates thereof.[
33] In fact, mental health records of a patient that did not have their origins in patient-mental health professional communication, such as records that refer to the fact of treatment or dates on which treatment was rendered, that simply show that a patient participated in certain activities, do not fall under the privilege.[
34]

Courts have held in some criminal cases that the psychiatric privilege will yield to a defendant's constitutional right of confrontation, if the psychiatric records are critical to the defense.[
35] In such a case, the criminal defendant must make a specific showing that “the evidence in question is critical to his defense and that substantially similar evidence is otherwise unavailable to him,” and “any communications not central to the defense must remain privileged and inadmissible at trial.”
[36]

In practice, the mental health privilege is applied much like that of the attorney-client privilege.[
37] Like the attorney-client privilege, the mental health privilege survives the death of the patient[38] and must be waived by the patient as a precondition to discovery.[
39] In the absence of an express statement of waiver by a patient, one seeking the disclosure of privileged mental health records must establish a waiver by the patient's decisive unequivocal conduct reasonably inferring the intent to waive.[
40] A patient's failure to object to a discovery request for psychiatric records does not constitute an affirmative waiver of the mental health privilege.[
41]

A patient may waive the privilege by calling his psychiatrist/psychologist as a witness and asking about his mental status.[
42] However, unlike in the case of other privileges, the mental health privilege is not waived simply because a party seeks to recover damages or otherwise places his mental state at issue.
O.C.G.A. § 24-12-1, which waives the privilege of confidentiality of medical records to the extent that medical care and treatment are placed at issue, specifically exempts psychiatrists from its coverage.[
43] The legislature has “clearly expressed its intent that, as a matter of public policy, [mental health] communications are to be privileged and are to remain privileged even though the patient's ‘care and treatment or the nature and extent of his injuries [have been put] at issue in any civil or criminal proceeding.’
”[44] The privilege is not waived simply because the person claiming it made disclosures in separate, unrelated actions.[
45]

In both federal and Georgia practices, the patient may waive the privilege by putting his mental health at issue.[
46] Both practices also recognize waiver when there is voluntary disclosure, including testimony.[
47] Finally, the Supreme Court in Jaffee hinted that the privilege may not apply when the patient poses a threat.[
48] While some circuits have adopted this approach,[49] others have stated that a duty to warn does not negate the privilege.[
50] Georgia has not adopted a similar exclusion. In the case of a decedent, the mental health provider has standing to invoke the privilege on behalf of a patient.[
51]
